turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi. How are you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, <UNIN/>, yeah. I'm all right, <UNSURE>thanks</UNSURE>. Um, though, I'm actually feeling a bit wheezy.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. My name is Doctor <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Like <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>I'm one of <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> that work for Babylon</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can I confirm your name and date of birth, please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: My, my name is, um, uh, Tina Smith.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And, I'm forty years old.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, are you in a space that's quiet and private?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah, yeah, yeah. I'm just, I'm <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, you mentioned that you are wheezy.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can you tell me a little bit more about that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. So, um, it started, like, about two days ago.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I don't know if it's because, you know, I was, like, cleaning the house. And, like, um, all this dust came out of the, the carpet. And, you know, I've always <UNIN/> thought that maybe I've got, uh, an allergy to, like, dust. Um, I think so. So, if it was triggered by

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, you know, two days later. Still not gonna be better. So.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, just getting a little bit worried about it now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, you were cleaning the house <UNIN/> two days ago. And, that's when it first started?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah. That's right.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did the wheezing start suddenly, or was it gradual?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, so, it started after maybe, uh, an hour or so <UNIN/> .

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, has it got worse over the past two days?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. So, <UNIN/> it get's a bit worse, um, at night, I find.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, have you taken anything for the wheeze?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no. No, I haven't actually.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And so, and the wheeze has been getting worse. And, today you're particularly worried. Is it because you're finding it hard to breathe or finding it hard to talk?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah. A bit of both actually. So, um, I'm feeling like a little bit, uh, uh, short of breath.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and, actually, when I'm, you know, talking, um, to my friends, I start finding that, uh, sometimes, um, I'm unable to <UNIN/>, complete my sentences.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, it can, it can get really bad, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, when you can breathe, and you take a deep breath, do you notice any pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mmm, no, no. No pain.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, have you noticed yourself feeling dizzy or the rooms spinning more than normal?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no. No dizziness. Uh, none of that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, have you been eating and drinking OK, particularly water?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah. I think I'm having, like, you know,  four or five glasses a day. Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, are you normally <UNSURE>fit and well</UNSURE>? Or do you have any other medical problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, actually, uh, I used to have, like, a bit of, um, asthma, uh, as a child.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and, also in the summer <UNSURE>I sometimes</UNSURE> get, um, hay fever.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, when you get hay fever, do you take any medications for it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, your asthma, did it resolve when you were a child?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I think mostly, yeah. I mean, sometimes when I, um, run for, like, long periods, it can, it can start up a bit. But, um, I have, uh, I have, like, an asthma inhaler. I use that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, do you still have your inhalers?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I think I might have one from, like, a couple of months ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But, you don't see your doctor regularly for asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no, I don't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, apart from this, do you know if you're allergic to anything?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, not that I know of.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, how far are you away from a doctor's surgery at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry, could you repeat that?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How far are you away from a doctor's surgery at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh,  they may be minutes' drive away.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, good.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, given that you've had a history of asthma when you were a child,

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, you get hay fever sometimes in the summer.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Your shortness of breath.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi. I've lost, um, video signal. Can you still hear me?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah. We just turned off.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, given you've got a history of asthma and

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: hay fever. This could be one of two things.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But, we want to rule out asthma or an allergy first.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, what you'll need <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> is visit one of our clinics, so we can do some more tests.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Such as check your <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Well what sort?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, the first thing we would do, is use a small device on your finger, to check the amount of oxygen in your blood.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, from that we can tell if it's asthma or something else.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Right, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Before this happens, if you've got something, like an <UNIN/> antihistamine, which you normally take for hay fever at home, I would take one, just in case it is an allergy you've had from the dust.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Uh, yeah. I don't have any antihistamines at home, unfortunately.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> You might be able to get one on your way to the doctor's surgery. If not, they can prescribe you one.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, OK. So, I can just get it over the counter then?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes. And it, they're normally about four to six pounds.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Is there anything else that you're particularly worried about, you want to ask me?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, um, not really. I mean.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I have, before, taken steroids for asthma. Um, I don't know if that's relevant.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes, that is. And, you may need to take some steroids now. But, we cannot, we, we won't be able to know until we've done those tests first.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Cool. So, I'm gonna write a letter for your GP, just to let him know what's happened. And, the consultation with the GP in person shouldn't take too long.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: All right. How long do you think it will take?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Probably ten minutes.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, that's great.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Cool. Um, you should get the letter over the app. And then, we can, you can take yourself to the GP.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: All right. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Cool.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, bye.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Thank you. Bye bye.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>
